sp.p: Old? ha! ha! he! Grutti, Grutti, dost heare him? ha! ha! he! prithee how old? how old dost thinke? have I not a warm moist palme? do's not my pulse beat strong, and healthy?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: The flowings of your blood, that downy chin, and these full veines, speake you— some twenty, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alp:
sp.p: And of complexion sanguine, I know it by my dreams.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.l: The rose-buds now are blooming on your cheekes,
And ope themselves into a crimson blush;
This haire curles up like wire, and and speakes you lusty,
Your strength is bold, and daring.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Belleeve it, I'me a wanton.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: Come let's to a wench then.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Hang marrying, t'is a slavery!

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: A meere purgatory!

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: An hell to be bounde to one, and shee prove false, ugly, or loude, when wee may enjoy our liberties, to take or leave 'em, as our stomack serves us; have the choice beautyes runne into our armes, and every night a fresh one.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Hey! to a Wench; to a Wench! capers !now an I were King it should bee treason for any subject to marry.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: Allow 'em but Wenches, and t'will be well enough.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Or to lye with a Woman.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: How would you doe for subjects then?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Perhaps an I had a minde to't, Ide get all my subjects my selfe, ha! what sayst thou to't, Grutti?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: I say t'is fit, you have a minde.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Bentivoglio! wee are friends, come thou shalt along with us, to a wench, old trangdido, to a wench, and thou shalt so bumfiddle her.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Nay, good my Lord, touch no more upon that string; but d'ee heare? I came to carry you to one.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Art right? art right? old boy! these Physitians are notable jerkers, come, where's their rendez-vous?

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: In my Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Ha? how many?— how many?— what's that there?

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: A draught to provoke.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: — Sleepe.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Nay good Bentivoglio give it mee, a whole one, a whole one!

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Be moderate; you'le take the next beggar you meete else; & then the Ladyes expectation yonder will be frustrate.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Ha! ha! he! Super naculum! my old bully lively, my authentick Don, soule of pleasure; line of life; let's too't; such a violent fit o'th sudden! a dozen Calentures are an ague to't; twenty Juleps will not coole one wish.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Let's have him to bed quickly, and b'ele him warme; Bonum erit si sudaverit,

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Foh! his breath stinkes oth University.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Signior tis not perfum'd:— now will I goe fetch these Ladyes to him; & if he have courage enough but to speak to 'em; I'le forfeit my art, and turne tooth-drawer.

div.head: ACT. III. SCEN. IV.
div.stage: A noyse within of clashing of Swords, some cry, treason! treason. Enter Ursini, and Valenzo fighting.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: My Lord!—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Villaine!

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: The injury! I am not any way conscious.—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Traytor thou lyest;
Hell, and thy selfe the greater mischiefe, has
Conspir'd to ruine goodnesse.—

div.stage: Enter the Guard with Piero, they seize on Valenzo. & exeunt.

div.head: ACT. III. SCEN. V.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Madame! y'have view'd these gardens;— has not art
Sweetely conspir'd with nature, to make up
A pleasure of variety?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: It takes exceedingly.—

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: What do's?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Pretty indeede,
To have these flowers reade morall lectures to us.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Yet Madame, you can finde in your heart to treade
Them underfoote, scorning as much the beauty,
As the rare sense they cary.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Yes I can,
Yet streight I turne, and plucke 'em;— binde 'em up,
In one faire volume, thus—

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: And what reade you, pray?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: The emblemes of true vertues in each leafe,
Imprinted there, at natures proper charges.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: What thinke you of this Lilly?

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.p: It figures innocence.

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: Weare it in your bosome.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Innocence indeed
Should be the breasts faire individuall mate.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: It will become you well.

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.l: So will this crowne Imperiall your head,
Pray stick it there.

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.l: I should be the envie of the Court then,
T'is a pretty flower, what think you if I carry it to the Princesse?

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.l: Fit, very apt and fit, lady,— as fit
A gift, as this were for a Lord, an hony-suckle,
The amorous woodbindes off-spring; it emblemes love;

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: You would not have us make love?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: This mysticke way has bin allow'd of;

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: And practis'd?

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.p: Yes, and practis'd.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Sure I should never do't.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: No Madame? why are not men creatures
As worthy Courtship, as wee?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Oh! but we are women!

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.p: Oh! but we are proud.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Shall I take't on your experience?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Or your owne:— hal whose voyce is that?

div.stage:
Song within.
My heart is big with griefe, my wombe with lust,
Both fruits of my too easie trust;
Breake first my heart, and it will be
To wofull mee
The welcomst, and most safe delivery.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Hence my delight! thou art turn'd traytour to mee:
Thy strings convey'd a poyson to my eares,
And they dranke deeply of it;— yet forbeare,
Alas it was my selfe, my inward griefe,
Throwne from the soule in often sighs, that made
Thy sound infectious; 'tis with that as guilt,
It growes still greater as 'tis borne about,
And poysons every thing should worke it's cure.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Is not this Sylvio, Calantha's Page?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: A lover growne? las pretty innocence.
How finely sorrow shewes there—! That, that passion
Is well express't; now sigh, then knock the breast. Excellent.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Let's use the benefit of this shade, to hide
Our selves, and secretly acquainted grow
With the blacke storie of his sad mishap.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Felicia.
How has thy name, thy selfe, thy friend deceiv'd thee!
That onely wert acquainted with the sound
Of happinesse; mock't with a false report,
Into a reall misery; whose easie nature
(The greatest foe unto it selfe, was flatter'd)
Out of a virgin treasure; and then left
Rifled of all; but (what griefe now is preying on)
A haplesse life— yet cruell theefe, th'ast left
So much of thee behind, as shall hereafter
Tell to the world a darke and gloomy tale
Of thy blacke perjury.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Ha! do's he riddle,
Or play with griefe?

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: No 'tis too like a truth.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Me thinkes each thing
I meete withall upbraids my fond credulity;
The soaring larke hovers aloft i'th aire,
At distance from th'inchanting glasse, that Courts
Her to her ruine! the fearefull Quaile
Suspects and shuns the musicke of the pipe
That sings her into fetters.
Onely poore I am sillier than these;
Witnesse th'untimely swelling of this wombe
Pregnant to my disgrace;— As I lay hid
In yonder thicket, the brambles gently swell'd,
And hid my shame, which yet each triviall winde
But dallying with, perswaded from my covert!
And left mee naked to heaven's eye; the boughs
Of the next willow clung about my head,
As if they'd knit themselves into a garland,
Which I should weare for my forsaken lover,—

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Very pretty!

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Wer't not so sad.

sp.speaker: Sylv:
sp.l: Oh you the weake supporters of my woes,
Why do'e faile mee now at greatest need?
Beare mee at least into some hollow cave
Where I may die, free from an after scorne;
And not when I am dead, be found the shame
Of our fraile sex;— Oh! I faint, and fall,
Just like the early branches of some tree,
Whose hasty sap shootes into early fruit,
Till the o're laden boughs cracke with the weight,
Ere yet they bee full ripe—

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.p: I am amaz'd, a woman!

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Some Lady here o'th Court, I'le lay my life on't;
Let's to the Princesse and informe her of it.

div.head: ACT. III. SCEN. VI.
div.stage: Ferrando. Ursini. (Valenzo, Piero, with guard about them.)

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: — Let mee eternally perish to honour,
If their heads answer not for this foule insolence.

sp.speaker: Urs:
sp.l: Though't be a sin of that portentous bulke,
That 't startles all the gods, and justice selfe
Wakes from a long dead lethargie to meete it:
Yet Kings are great as they, and spight of fate
Or rigorous lawes, may triumph in their mercy.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: Away with 'em to execution;
Him, and his fellow murderer, away:
— Pardon a Traytour?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Though you might urge, 'twere treason of that height,
That none but they could thinke of, much lesse act:
That murder cries for murder, blood for blood:
That he whose innocence they sacrific'd
To their mad fury, was your loyall subject;
This on your marriage day— to affront Hymen.
And when your nuptiall torch burnt brightest, dead it
With bloud, into a sickly glimmmering taper:
That they should dare assault me!— i'th' Court—
One whom your goodnesse has bin pleas'd to looke
Into a life, and honours, plac't i'th' state,
Only to interpose my selfe betweene,
And meet all dangers that are shot at you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'Twas a murder
Intended on our person, but that Heaven—

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Was just in the prevention; True it might be so,
And were it, yet upon submission
Such faults have beene remitted.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Away with 'em, I'le heare no more.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Downe holy anger!—
One word, and I'me gone— you are my Soveraigne,
And there's divinitie worne in that title,
Which I adore, and thinke my selfe as happy
In this so early doome, since you are pleas'd with't,
As heaven had spoke it; though not till old age,
When nature claim'd it as a due! Yet Sir
Be gentle to my memory; and if
At any time my crimes appeare before you,
Fresh in your thought, to staine my Heraldrie,
The happy mention of my vertuous acts,
From some that love my dust, shall rise to pleade
My innocence—; and may you never live
To curse th' untimely hand; or houre that rob'd you
Of so much loyaltie!— for you Ursini—
If ere your name shall fall in mention, when
I come i'th other world, expect me not
Your friend; I feare me, I shall tell sad tales
In th'eares of heaven;— Farewell—

div.stage: Exeunt Val. Pier. with a guard.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Impudent Traytour!

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Yet still I dare be good; and spight of all
His hate, or malice to me, thus stand up
To begge his life.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Not after so much injury?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Yes, if Valenzo dare be sinfull still
In wrongs, it shall be call'd my piety
To suffer.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Th'art all goodnesse;— for thy sake
Wee'le mixe some mercy with our doome,
He that submits first to thee, has his pardon,
See justice done on th'other; this sentence
Shall stand irrevocable;—

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: This sentence stand irrevocable?
Plague to your easie nature!—
Ha! this 'tis to over-act; how have I almost fool'd my self, out
Of my owne plots;
I were in a fine case now, if Piero
Should not accept a life on this condition.
I'le send to him— Cassio! Grutti! who waites there?—

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ladies, pray absent your selves a while;—
— With child? impudent whore! to what curs'd lumpe
Have thy sinnes swolne thee?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Oh, me miserable!

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Hence ingrate wretch! that hast abus'd my favours
So farre, till thou hast made a sin of charitie:
— Ha! dost weepe?—
My rare dissembler! those teares which art hath taught
To flow, carry more sinfull cunning in 'em,
Then those the flattering Syrens weare upon
Their cheekes, when they court man to ruine:
Yet tell me ere you goe, whom have those lookes
Beguil'd, and train'd into your sinfull armes.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: You must prepare your selfe for a sad story then:

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Yes, like enough, a tale as sad, and dismall
As that of Troy, and as much truth in't too!
Quickly, dispatch, before my anger prove
Too masculine!— and be modest in'th relation.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: You'le wish't untold.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Undone I doe! but why
This tedious circumstance? it do's involve
Your guilt.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Know then, that when I was my selfe
My name was—

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Felicia

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Alberto's daughter?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Yes his— that was once Alberto
Durazzo's farre-fam'd Marquesse; till
His cruell Master seiz'd on's life, and honours,
At his returne from Sicily i'th first warres;
Where he receiv'd a fatall overthrow.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: He was in action bold, and valiant!
However fortune wrought him this disgrace;

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Here! here began my misery.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Proceede, trust me I now begin to pitty thee.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Then let me die without your farther knowledge
Of my mishap; t'will be injurious
Unto my ashes, and disturbe their quiet;
I know it will;

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Nay, prithee tell me, come, and I'le weepe with thee.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: You'le have cause enough ere I've done;
Therefore don't hear't;

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Is there ought in't concernes me?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Too much

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Nay, then I must, and will have all the story,
Or thinke thee a foule prostitute.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: 'Tis thus then!
— Yet do'nt beleeve me, say that I was mad,
Distracted with my sorrowes, that my words
Fell so uneven from me, you mistooke
The sense; say any thing.—

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Come, come, I know thou wilt tell truth!

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Or may I never finde peace hereafter!

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: How I feare
Whether this story tends?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: The King Madame.
Ferrando;— (Seize me Courteous death,
Or I shall poyson all her joyes;)

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ha! what of him?
Be sudden, or, I sweare by my just anger,
I'le streight rip up the cradle of thy lust,
The den where all thy loose adultery's
Were acted; search each corner of thy wombe.
That keepes a record of thy villanyes!

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Ferrando was the author of my fall:

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: More lying then that evill Genius
That wrought the first mans fall!

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Ferrando! oh! oh! (Swoons)

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Thou rebell passion jealousy! what mean'st thou
To tumult in my breast?— ha! yet why not?
Why may not he be false?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Oh! oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: T'is so!— Felicia!— she's gone, she's gone!
Helpe there, Florinda! Violetta! Ladyes!
Soe— she begins to breath;— looke up Felicia!

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Where am I?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Here,— a medall? this confirmes it;
sp.stage: finds a medall about her necke with the pict: of Fer: & Fel. in it
sp.l: Ferrando and Felicia!

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Ha! the Princesse!
Beshrew me but I've had a fearefull dreame!
I hope t'was but a dreame;

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: No; I know all,
Ferrando's false, as stayn'd with sin, and perjury
As howling-Ghosts.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Good Madame don't affright me;
Your fancy's darke and gloomy.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Yes all hell
Is there at worke contriving a revenge;

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Revenge? for whom?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: No matter whom;— But tell me
How, and with what false othes, he won thee first
To his loose sheets.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: I'le tell you; but you first
Shall promise me, to breade no other way
To your revenge and mine, then I shall leade you in.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I doe:
Let's sir, and heare it all.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Whilst yet Alberto liv'd
As great in favour as in bloud, the glory
O'th Court of Naples, honour'd with dayly visits
From his Prince; t'was my unhappy destiny,
(Foole that I was to be so credulous!)
To receive many favours from Ferrando;
Which I interpreted i'th way of love;
Meane while, this match was treated of betweene
Him, and your selfe; your Father (Sicily's King)
After your plighted troths, and formall ceremonyes
Us'd betwixt Prince, and Prince, would breake it off,
Which caus'd a sudden warre upon his Country;
In which expedition Alberto
Was sent chiefe generall: the King being fore't
Now to withdraw his publick visits, imploy'd
Ursini in the businesse; gets accesse
Privately to me i'th might, and that too
Allwayes i'th darke, lest happily he might
Be knowne to any of my servants; Briefly
After his many oathes, and protestations
Of his faire meaning, I at last consented
To let him steale the fruit, he durst not owne:
When ere I urg'd, he was ingag'd to you,
He answer'd, that was but a tricke of state,
A faire pretence to colour his designe;
And mak't seeme glorious, in the eye o'th world;
That he warr'd for a Kingdome, not a Queene;
Onely intreated me, that I'de be silent,
And not so much as in a signe betray
To'th day, what onely night was conscious of.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: You condiscended?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Willingly.
My father i'th meane while returnes defeated,
For which the King led on by passion, seiz'd
His life and honours, these conferr'd on his
Now favourite Ursini: the fleete re inforc't,
He himselfe the second time in person
Went generall of the forces, conquer'd Sicily,
And slew your father on Messina's plaines,
Last brought you away captive.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: But how cam'st thou to Court in Sicily?
Thou told'st another story then:

sp.speaker: Syl:
sp.l: For that
I crave your pardon, 'twas all the untruths
My life has ere bin charg'd with; but 'twas thus:
Led partly by a jealous feare, to see
What he intended; partly to find out
My brother Frederico, who was left there
Commander in Mazara, which was tooke
In the first expedition, in this disguise,
'Mongst others whom desire of fame, or profit
Led to your shore, I cross't the seas; but failing
In quest of him I sought, I came to Court,
Where since I have remain'd.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: But why Felicia
Did'st not disclose thy selfe before this time,
Now things are growne so bad?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: When first I saw
Your person, and how mutually you lov'd,
Knowing how farre I was beneath your worth,
So deare I held you both, that I determin'd
For ever to be lost to memory;
And serve you thus in this disguise: which I
Had done, but that this haplesse chance
Betray'd mee to your knowledge.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Alas! thy piety has undone us both!

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: 'Twas my too cruell destinies!

sp.speaker: Cal,
sp.l: Methinkes wee two now seeme to be set copies
Of griefes, to which wrong'd virgins will repaire,
To take out patternes by.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Our wrongs and sorrowes
Have made us just so like to one another,
That each seemes th'o others counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: We'le sit, and descant on our miseries,
Count the extent of each, proportion teares,
And sighs unto them.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Her's that doth surmount,
Shall borrow griefe of t'other.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: H'as robb'd mee of a father cruell Tyrant,

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: H'as robb'd mee of a father cruell Tyrant,

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Bereav'd mee of my friends, and loving subjects,

sp.speaker: Syl:
sp.p: Bereav'd mee of my Brother, and my friends.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Tane away all my honours, and my dower.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Taken my virgin honour, all my dower.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: H'as mock't mee with the title of a Queene.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: H'as mock't mee with the title of a Queene.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: — But I am lost in Passion.

sp.speaker: Sylv:
sp.p: And I am lost in Passion.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Felicia come, and as our wrongs are equall,
So let our revenge be; we'le hand in hand
Assault this Tyrant; and in bloody Characters
Print on his body the story of our sufferings:

sp.speaker: Syl:
sp.p: Yet this cannot cure our griefe.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: What though, wrong'd innocence?
In death it will intitle us to honours;
And though our bodies moulder to corruption,
Our better part shall survive fame; our names,
Free from decay, shall swell up numerous volumes;
Whil'st our sad legends shall be made a pillow,
To every sleeping virgin.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: O yet for my sake have some pitty on him,
And for that part of him, that's cradled here,
'Las he may live to make us faire amends.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: For thy sake I could spare him, but my wrongs
Sit heavy here, and urge mee to revenge.

sp.speaker: Syl:
sp.l: But say l've thought a way, how we may yet
Be both restor'd to happinesse, would you not
Accept, and follow't?

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Speake it (gentle soule.)

sp.speaker: Syl:
sp.l: As yet (you know) your virgin treasure stands
Free from his ruder touch: those Ceremonies,
Which link't you in one Hymeneall knot,
Religion will make void, the praecontract
'Twixt him and mee being knowne, so that you then,
On this part are free from him; enjoy him thus
You cannot, neither would you (I suppose)
After these wrongs, (if you might be permitted:)
What hinders then, but that I take your place
This night? and shew him, to what height his perjury
Has wrought our wrongs, whilst you in some disguise
May quit the Court, and e're next Sun appeare,
From hence towards France, to whom you are allyed
In blood, and wrongs.—

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Content,— I'le in, and haste mee to be gone,
To goe there is some hope.

sp.speaker: Syl:
sp.p: To stay there's none.

div.head: SCEN. I.
div.stage: Piero. Cassio. as in the Prison.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.p: — To mee this?

sp.speaker: Cass:
sp.l: Out of particular respect
Hee stood ingag'd to repay your merits.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.l: Dare you
Promise so much for's Lordship?

sp.speaker: Cass:
sp.l: The Contents
Of that will speake, how much he tenders goodnesse
In every noble breast.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.l: No doubt Sir, but
You are familiar with the sense it carries,
And can informe mee, better than the darke Character.

sp.speaker: Cass:
sp.l: 'Tis that you'd be pleas'd t'accept
A life, for which to's Piety you shall owe,
Onely a faire acknowledgement.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.l: Wondrous good!
'Tis a becomming charity this, and hee
Weares it amongst the chiefest of his vertues.

sp.speaker: Cass:
sp.l: Sir, it must needs be eminent in's Lordship,
Since exercis'd upon so noble a subject
As your selfe

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.l: But stay?— now I thinke on't,
This is a benefit of that nature, it seldome comes
Alone, are there not honours too? preferments
That wait upon this gift? speake, shall I be
His Lordships creature?

sp.speaker: Cass:
sp.p: He's passionately yours.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.l: Are we not for designe?— ba, what darke tricke
Is there i'th State, that doth imply danger
Enough for us to mannage, doth he thinke
Us fit to temper poysons, or use the benefit
O'th night to seize on his State-rivals, are we
Potent enough for faction, or intended
Intelligencer to some forraine Prince?

sp.speaker: Cass:
sp.p: What meane you?

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Ingagements of this nature urge a returne
Of thankes proportionable to themselves,
And what we have of such rich values,
I cannot tell, lest t'be our soules forfeited
To'th next occasion his Lordship has to use 'em.

sp.speaker: Cass:
sp.l: This is strange language Sir, my understanding
Has not yet arriv'd at what it meanes.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.l: Go home and study it then:— and do'e heare,
Entreat my Lord, t'employ his favours to
Some further profit, he'le scarce be gainer by 'em else.

sp.speaker: Cass:
sp.p: I shall acquaint him with your humour.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.p: Do maggot, wriggle, wriggle, do:—

div.head: ACT. IV. SCEN. II.
div.stage: To Piero, Charintha; (Valenzo behinde the hangings.)

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Piero.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Madame! I am all joy, life, honours,
Preferment, and what not?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Then I'me undone!
Piero! didst not promise me to stand
The utmost of's temptations? didst thou boast
Thy vertuous strength, and fall'st at the first onset?

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.p: Life Madame is sweet.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: If hitherto
It hath bin so, hereafter t'will be all
Bitternesse, thou hast betray'd thy friend to death;
The thought of which will soure all thy content,
Make thy best pleasures rellish worse then gall.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Life, with the worst that can befall us, is
A good exchange for death; but here are honours
Annex't to't Lady! I shall be great in favour.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Thou wilt grow big in sinne too! thou must barter
Thy vertue for preferment; which being gone,
At best thou't be but painted ruines,
A glorious misery; thou must owe life
To him, that will infect and kill thy soule.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Yet you would be content, Valenzo should
Accept a life, on this condition.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Yet he may live, and still be vertuous.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.p: Why? so may I.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Yet he's thy friend.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.p: Am not I his too?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: T'will be a glory to thee after death
That thou wert friendships martyr, a title
Will sit upon thy tombe, richer than all
Thy Heraldry; more lasting than thy marble.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: To shew how farre, I can preferre him to
My selfe, I am content this honour should be his.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.l: False to thy friend, and vertue! that onely cam'st
To mocke calamitie, and midst our wrongs
Remaine our greatest in jurie.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Mistake mee not,
I onely did prepare you for a joy,
Which now you're ripe for:— know then, 'T return'd
Him scorne for all his flattering promises;
And stood resolv'd t'incounter with his fury,
Made hot by my disdaine.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: Miracle of friendship.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Since 'tis decreed that one of us must fall,
And onely one, my death shall free us both
From the lawes rigour, enjoy your best Valenzo,
Enjoy him long, may you (a happy paire)
Grow like two neighbouring roses on one stalke,
Partaking mutually each others sweetes;
Whence no rude hand approach to ravish you,
But when you are full blowne, and ripe for heaven,
May you fall gently both into one grave,
There lye intomb'd in your owne odours.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Piero, thou go'st
To heaven, to be the envy of the Saints;
For when thou com'st where those blest troopes reside,
No man shall ere direct a vow, or prayer,
But unto thee!— Valenzo take thy friend, (Val: Enters)
Take him unto thy bosome, he has so much
Of heaven in him, I feare he can scarce die.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.l: Is it your feare, Madame? can he deserve lesse in
Your faire opinion, than to be thought immortall?
That death at length should boast a victory
O're so much goodnesse.— Methinkes (Piero)
Thou should'st for ever stand a rich example,
To all mankind, who in thy fall will sicken,
And dye to vertue; injoy the happinesse
Of thine owne fate; I will not rob thee of
One precious minute; live till time has powr'd
A reverend snow upon thy head.—

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.p: But justice must be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.p: I'le bow my selfe beneath the stroake.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.l: To slay
The innocent, is not to expiate,
But make a crime, preserve thy selfe entire
To thy Charintha, King, and Country.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.l: What!
And betray my friend to death?

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: To what
I have deserv'd.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.l: T'was thy too forward zeale, and a ripe spirit.
That spur'd thee on to action, thou didst it for
Thy friend, for mee, and had not justice bin
Wrong'd in't, the honour had bin mine, why not
The shame?

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.p: You must not, shall not die.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.l: No more!
'Twill prove a breach of friendship else, I must not,
Shall not die: my honour suffers double,
Thou wouldst foyle mee both in love, and valour.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.p: Pitty these teares.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.l: Or in thy ruine I
Am lost.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.l: Justice requires but one, her fate
Is so involv'd in yours, you cannot fall,
But in it shee must finde a certaine death;
Thinke then, how can you satisfie the law?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Farre easier than you, in whose sad losse
The whole world suffers, and in thy unripe fall
Looses all goodnesse.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.l: Stint this pious strife,
I have bin too much woman, and betrai'd
My name to infamy, in this tame passion:
Possesse mee a just anger, a spirit great
And noble as my birth; that I may shake,
And rowze this sleepy Prince, from his dull lethargie;
Who's wholy lost, in the bewitching flatteries
Of that bad man;— alas this is a danger
Too potent for your starres to free you from;
Henceforth I'le be your destinies: for since
This calme brings nothing but a certaine fall,
A storme shall either save, or ruine all.

div.head: ACT. IV. SCEN. III.
div.stage: A Table is set forth; taper, pen, inke, &c.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Contemne our pardon.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Returne your favours too
With so much scorne.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: Better they'd play'd with lightning,
Or hugg'd a thunderbolt.

sp.speaker: Urs:
sp.l: Justice is slow
Of pace, and if not led by furie,
Seldome o'retakes the crime, let your returne
Of punishment be quicke, and active, delay is worse
Than pitty, and more dangerous: Valenzo
Is popular, and who knowes, but hee had rather,
Owe his life to the peoples mutiny, than your pardon,
And therefore slighted it.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: Oh the state of Princes!
How farre are we from that securitie,
Wee dream't of in th'expectance of our crowne?
Were forraine dangers nothing, yet we nourish
Our ruine in our bosome: Valenzo is a traytour,
So is Piero too; and who is not in this age?
It is unsafe not to suspect our selfe.
To torture with 'em; be noble in thy justice:—
Here draw a warrant for their execution;—
We'le sign't with our owne signer;— hence pitty,
Post from our breast; we banish thee our bosome
Th'art a disease bred there to ruine Majestie: Ursini preparing to write.
And sink us below our subjects scorne.—

sp.speaker: Charintha?
sp.l: Our Princely cousin, welcome to Court; thou hast
Beene too long absent, (I must chide thee for't,)
And envy'd us the boast of vertue.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: Vertue!

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Some malicious devill now, or other,
Has intic'd her from her beads;
To undoe mee, and my plots, shee carries anger
In her brow:— this I must mitigate, or I am
Lost.—

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: Thou art so eager after heaven,
Thou woo't o're-buy thy happinesse.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: Never fear't Sir.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: But thy devotion's season'd with so much charity,
Thou pil'st a stocke of merit up for us
At Court.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: I beleeve y'had need on't.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: As long as we live here we shall;—

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: So wicked!

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: Ha! what frowne's that, whence these clouds, Charintha?
So rises the blushing morne, as thou wert wont
To smile, when thou appear'dst, we owe
Our day unto thy eyes; and if thou think'st
Thy beautie's worne too cheape, we'le become tributaries
To thee for light; chase hence this sullen darknesse,
Thy absence has already made too long
A night.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: No Sir; 'twas your blacke deeds.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: How's this?
Do'e know mee, who I am?

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: Not well.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Your King.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.l: A Tyrant
Of bigge, and grorious impietie's,
A regall monster, the true head of that
Beast you rule, the multitude: more cruell
Than enrag'd lyons, or robb'd beares; who both
Will spare the innocent, and humble.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Looke to'th Lady there, sure she's distracted.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: My wrongs indeed would make mee so.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: What wrongs? whence? or from whom?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Raise not my auger higher with your scorne;—

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: By all that's.—

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Or if't be ignorance of my sufferings,
It but betrayes your want of reason, and
How farre you're lost to man, by your fond dotage.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Grow more particular, or wonder ruines mee.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Good God! I've suffer'd so long, till patience
Grew my greatest crime.—

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Now, now the storme is coming this way,
But I'me prepar'd to meete it.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Whence? or from whom?
Aske this good man how often he has mourn'd
Over the ruines of my fame? how often
His eares have met with the report of my
Disgrace? how I was noys'd a strumpet? when
Each talking thing at Court, might freely act
A rape upon my vertue, till I was left
All a whole staine, blacke as the front of perjur'd
Sinners? while you, (as if I'de bin a trifle
Cast from your blood, and kindred, or some darke thing,
Whose actions were so fowly bad.
That report better'd 'em in the expression:)
Could sit as silent as the night; as calme
As seas, when the windes sleepe; yet at last be just;
And say, how have I appear'd to you, or him,
That calumnie has thus bin priviledg'd,
To violate my honour?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Madame,
I have allwayes spoke you, chastities best example.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Innocence it selfe is not so white.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Yet he that would confirme this with his sword,
Must meete, with prisons, wrackes, and tortures,
As a reward of so much vertue!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Sweetest Princesse!—

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.l: And ere he die, must suffer in's honour,
Be proclaim'd traytor to the state:

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Ursini, thou hast abus'd our trust.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: My Lord.—

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.l: Too weake pretence, for your ingratitude
To so large merit; Naples call's him
Her chiefe preserver; he brought home victory,
By his owne arme atchiev'd, when the proud foe,
Threatned your Kingdome with a fatall downefall.
He, to whose arme you owe your life, your crowne,
To whom in warre, you'd sooner flie for helpe
Then to the Altar; now in peace must have
His temples robb'd; his garlands from his brow
Transplanted. to adorne this uselesse statua.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Madame, I have not so appear'd in managing these affaires of yours.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Would thou had'st,
Or somewhat that carries lesse resemblance
Of man: Oh thou art bravely wicked.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: I have not us'd the art to boast the vertue
Of mine owne actions; yet heaven knowes
They were all good, and aim'd at ends as honourable
As your desires.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ursini leave, till there is hope of pardon,
This impudence in sinne,
Bid's a defiance to all mercy; did we not,
At your perswasion, give order for Valenzo's
Quicke dispatch?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: How ere I seem'd( great Sir) to runne downe with the streame of your violent passion, yet my intents still bore up against it; witnesse this paper.
sp.stage: Deliver's a paper to Ferrando, who reades it.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Ha! What's here a pardon?

sp.speaker: Urs:
sp.p: Which you had seal'd ere this, had not this Lady here interrupted it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Urs:
sp.l: your passion would not have permitted you,
To have o're view'd what you consented too;
This I knew, as likewise how dangerous it
Would have beene to the state, if he had fall'n.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: Againe my owne Ursini:—
Charintha, pardon our errours, we will deserve it,
By the future love, and honours we will throw
On our Valenzo,— here take my signer
Fetch 'em to Court.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: You are noble.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Ursini Waite on her to the Castle.

sp.speaker: Urs:
sp.p: You honour mee.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Oh how neere were we destruction.
Reason sit still enthron'd in thine owne state,
T'is passion onely ruines Kings, not fate.

div.head: ACT. IV. SCEN: IV.
div.stage: Bentivoglio. Alphonso. Grutti. Cassio. Violetta. Florinda.

sp.speaker: Bent:
sp.p: Hold up, hold up Sir, the Ladies are comming this way,— for shame,— God's mee, they'r here; why do'e tremble so Sir?

sp.speaker: Alph:
sp.p: A violent fit o'th ague; oh! oh! oh! have mee to bed gently, gently, or I shall scatter all my limbes;

sp.speaker: Bent:
sp.p: Discredited for ever, (here take this staffe Sir)— have I boasted your strength to them?— fortifi'd you for th' incounter, and you faile me thus?— undone, undone!

sp.speaker: Alph:
sp.p: Oh! oh! oh! for halfe a dozen of night caps.

sp.speaker: Bent:
sp.p: Here Sir, on with 'em; they'r somewhat durty, they'll keepe you the warmer;— now shall I be call'd Mountebanke; Quackesalver, Pispot-peeper: and all the ugly mangy names can be invented.— come in, come in.—

sp.speaker: Grut:
sp.p: 'Twill be a Scene of modest mirth, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: The Physitian has cool'd him.

sp.speaker: Bent:
sp.p: Why Sir, you won't disgrace mee? go towards 'em.

sp.speaker: Alph:
sp.p: Some fire, some fire;— cold, cold, cold, cold.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Here, here, on with my gowne:— this cap, so, so.

sp.speaker: Grut:
sp.p: Ladies, we'le take leave to be bold here to vexe him.

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: How do'e my Lord?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: We are come here to await your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: The very thought on't has cast him into a cold sweat.

sp.speaker: Alph:
sp.p: Oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Cass:
sp.p: Now for fifty virgins.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: A monopoly of women.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Hey, for a wench, for a wench, to bumfiddle now; Ah! ha!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Oh! ho! oh!

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Do'e remember you'd play the foole in my gowne, and cap excellently.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Well said Doctour.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: To him Doctour.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Then a noyse of Musitians would do rarely.

sp.speaker: Cass:
sp.p: Looke he's nodding.

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: My Lord you intend no abuse to us?

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.p: Make us hazzard our credits for nothing?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: More clothes;— why hoe there, on my feete I say.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: He's dreaming.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Fast, fast a sleepe, so, so, this charme last's till Midnight, and then hee wakes.

sp.speaker: Grut:
sp.p: 'Twill be good sport to see him then—

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Dance up and downe the Court like the ghost of old Hippocrates.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: You must not expose him to the publike view.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: Mr Doctour you're sufficiently reveng'd, this is enough for you to boast on when you come i'th University.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: This, and the rare cures I've done upon you two shall be my theame.— Good night.— Ladies I'me your servant.— My doughty placket-hunter lye thee there, and e'ne awake when thy stomacke serves thee; to morrow morning I'me for Padua.—

sp.speaker: Zisc.
sp.l: The night comes on apace, streight every thing
Will be as blacke as I, and alike terrible,
Nay out-doe mee too: each leafe that stirres
Affrights the fearfull, makes the guilty tremble,
And yet this night, what is it but a shadow?
Yet I am lesse than that, for I do lesse:
I that have purpos'd so much, act nothing!
Horrour! could but my thoughts be seene, they'd owne
Murders, more than the basiliske could commit,
Were he all eye, more than revenge has acted,
Or than the triviall spight of plague, and warre
Produce, in their full heate.— Ursini be speedy
Or I'le outrunne designe.—

sp.speaker: Urs:
sp.p: Zisco.

sp.speaker: Zisc.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Urs:
sp.l: The houres are favourable
And have brought opportunitie along with 'em,
We must resolve for action.

sp.speaker: Zis.
sp.p: I'me prepar'd.

sp.speaker: Urs:
sp.p: But Zisco, art thou sure Felicia was.—

sp.speaker: Zis.
sp.l: Sure? puh! would you know? I my selfe
Am the Moore he caus'd to ravish her.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: And canst thou do't againe?

sp.speaker: Zis.
sp.p: Bravely.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: This night then thou shalt— ravish his Mistris,
Calantha! this night! I've prepar'd all things ready
For thy conveyance into her chamber— thou wilt doe't

sp.speaker: Zis.
sp.p: Resolv'd.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: And kill her too?

sp.speaker: Zisc.
sp.p: An shee were my mother.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Obscure your selfe a while.— how now?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.l: My Lord, the French have kept their word,
And unespied have stolne from Genoa,
Enter'd our haven, and this night have set
Upon our fleete, the bold Sicilians too
I'th towne are up in armes.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: There spoke my Genius.

sp.speaker: Cass:
sp.l: My Lord! the Cittie's in a mutinie,
The Court in wild distraction.

sp.speaker: Urs:
sp.p: Well, beyond my hopes: excellent well; Grutti, Cassio, be nere us, we must use your helpe to night.

sp.speaker: Cass:
sp.l: Valenzo playes from the Castle with his Canons,
And strikes both parties without distinction:
He's now marching up with a well ord'red troope,
T'is thought he had intelligence of your intents.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: O my fate! that man undoe's mee.
Thus early sins are blasted in the bud,
There is no safety but in being good.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.l: — 'Tis late.
Each man retire to his quarter: Captaines,
We entertaine your merit with a serious welcome.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: Our deserts, my Lord,
Are so slender, that wer't not to prejudice
Your judgement, we would blush to owne any.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.p: Hang this flattery, merit quotha? is't such a piece of merit to cut a score or two of throats; knocke downe an hundred o'th citty herd? a gallant could do so much for's Cockatrice.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.p: The King shall give you each particular thinkes: He owes you both a trophey,

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: His acknowledgement
Of our duty, would raise our pride to sinne,
We should forget to let heaven share i'th victory.

sp.speaker: Cont:
sp.p: Victories, by Mars's crest it deserves not to come i'th Chronicle, though Hollinshead or Hall, those voluminous forreiners should write our annals, 'twill ne're make us justle in among the Caesars, or owne a name i'th list o'th worthies.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No Contareno, wee will not have thee painted in vile ugly colours, and clapt upon chimneies, thou shalt be cut—

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.p: In brasse? mine would make an excellent brazen face?

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.l: In Parian marble, wee'le rob the Quarries
To reare thee up a glorious monument.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.p: A glorious loame to set lazie spiders a worke in, an office for birds to mute in, if these be your glorious monumēts for men of armes, I'le e'en live to sin out my merit (as you call it) then when I die, the world and I will shake hands, and cry quit of all sides.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Hee that should heare thee talke thus, and not know
thee well, would doubt thy valour.

sp.speaker: Cont:
sp.p: Hercules! an hee did he should try it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: T'were punishment enough.
Gonçales— I gratulate thy navall victory;
France will have cause hereafter to mention thee in sad story,
Thou giv'st them but a churlish salutation.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Such as they deserv'd,
It seemes they came rather to steale than fight,
They were as ill prepar'd, as they had meant
To beare our empty hulkes away unquestion'd;
For soone as they perceived we descri'd 'em,
Pale, as the lillies in their trembling flagges,
They turn'd their sailes, and fled; we made after 'em,
With swift wing'd lightning from our Canons mouth,
Which sunke and fir'd 'em all, ere they could quit
The channell, or gaine the wider Ocean;

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Beleeve mee, noble Souldier, thou art deare
To fame; as old in victory, as in yeares,
Yet still thou toyl'st t'undoe thy selfe, and benefit
Thy ingratefull soyle, which never will be able
To requite thy meanest service.

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.l: Yet you for the same cause, i'th pride of youth,
Oppos'd your selfe betwixt the state and danger,
When their sicke hopes, were as their fortunes, desperate;
Reduc'd a Kingdome to your sway, in whose
Rich spoyles, your gawdie Souldier triumphs;
Whilst boasting of their rifled plumes, they drinke
Health's to victory; yet those so moderate,
Their bowles encrease their fury, not their surfeits.

sp.speaker: Cont:
sp.p: How these tall men o'th sword claw one another?

sp.speaker: Gal:
sp.p: They have an itch of pride runnes through 'em.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The Hero's, when thou com'st into Elyzium,
To give thee place, shall shift their blessed mansions.

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.p: And load thee with their lawrells.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: How my feares betray mee! shunning
One toyle, I runne into another.

sp.speaker: Cont:
sp.p: Che va la?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Oh mee! I'me surpriz'd.

sp.speaker: Cont:
sp.p: Spirit of valour th'art my prisoner.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Ha! whom have you there?

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: (Valenzo! my voyce betrayes mee.)

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: A young Sicilian, shall I draw my steele,
And give him a gentle stroke?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Lend mee my sword— and be thou what thou wilt I dare thee to thy worst.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.p: Bravely spoke,— set forward then.—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Traytour! the Princesse! Calantha!

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: All the better; she's skilfull at her weapon,
We'le but exchange a thrust in sport.

sp.speaker: Gal. & Gon.
sp.p: Ha! what meanes this flight?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Dare none of you fight?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Deare Lady, not with you.

sp.speaker: Cal,
sp.l: Then you are cowards, they speake you so i'th Citty,
And I came out thus purposely to try you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: If you please, you shall quickly see that,
Command us sheath our swords in one anothers
Bosomes— we'le fly like lightning to execute your
Commands;— you're our Princesse.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: No, I'me your Prince's murthresse.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: I've kill'd your King: will none
Dispatch mee yet?

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.p: Sure she's distracted.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.l: We must disarme you Lady;— t'is a duty to our Prince
Was never till now unwillingly perform'd!
You must backe to'th Court, whither we'le waite upon you.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Villaines, cowards,

sp.speaker: Gal:
sp.p: The Princesse! what made shee abroad so late?

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.p: Did she not say that shee had kill'd the King too?

sp.speaker: Gal:
sp.p: Come let's walke the round; things are yet unsetled.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.p: 'Tis so darke now, an the divell should lye perdieu I should go neere to stumble on's hornes.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Too much of this sad story, Oh these men
How are they degenerate from the goodnesse
Of their creation! they have beene alwaies false—

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Silly as we are,
We know it; their vowes and othes are traytours
To us, and yet we hugge them, let them into our bosomes,
Into our hearts, till they undoe us?

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.l: But Madame, why do'e desire us to leave you?
Fear you not his fury, what it may prompt him too,
When he shall see you are not his Calantha.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: He never was acquainted with that passion,
He's violent in nothing,— But in love.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: And yet he may dissemble that too
As well as his vowes.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Should hee? were his hand
Lift up to strike mee, I can charme it there!
Who can looke on a Ladies bended knees,
Wet cheekes, swolne eyes, heare her sighs, her prayers,
And yet be cruell: If there be one that can,
That one is not Ferrando; his bosome is
Passable to every grone; it strikes his heart:
He would tell mee (when he was absent)
If I sigh't, or wept, for then he said
He wept and sigh'd by sympathy.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Yet now he loves you not.

sp.speaker: Fel:
sp.l: Can hee not love himselfe? here, here I beare him,
Himselfe in a lesse modell, this I'le shew him,
If he mistrust t'is none of his; let him
But rip mee up, there he shall see each limbe
As like to his, as his one hand, one eye,
One cheeke is like the other: besides there lyes
Folded by his owne name, he told mee hee
Would call it so, (Ferrando,) and lest I
Should chance forget, I wrote it in my heart,
There he will finde it.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Good Lady!

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: T'is a sad nuptiall night, this,

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: I'le tell him too how hee
Would grieve if I were dead, goe hanging downe
His head, vailing his eyes from heaven, asham'd
To looke up to the place, where his Felicia is:
Or poring on the ground, as he would finde
Where my neglected ashes lay a sport
To th' windes; where some rude blast might blow mee up
Into his eyes, and then hee'd weepe to finde,
Mee there; weepe till the fretting brine had burn'd
His eye-bals out.
He told mee of his dreames, what pleasure hee
Had to finde me in 'em: alas they will
Be terrible now: I shall affright him, appeare
A thin pale ghost, make him start out in his sleepe;
(Alas! I will not) yet he'le dreame he heard mee.
Cry out, Ferrando! revenge upon Ferrando:
This cannot chuse but startle him.—

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: Heaven grant it may.

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.l: Madame all joy that we can hope, or wish,
Be with you.

sp.speaker: Fer:—
sp.l: I'le goe alone into the bed-chamber.
There expect him,— pray leave mee.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Good night, I heare him coming.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Our Navie victour.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: The City quiet too I those clouds
Which threatned ruine to your Kingdome, all
Blowne o're; the skie serene and calme, as if
It laugh't at your vaine feares; the lampes of heaven
That now seem'd all blowne out, are trimm'd a new
And brighter shine, to lead you to Elyzium.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: To Heaven, Elyzium's poore to what wee shall
Enjoy to night.

sp.speaker: Urs:
sp.l: The land of some dull villager
Or doughty Poëts dreames.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: The birth of fancie,
A thin, fantasticke, aierie paradise;
With which they flatter their weake hopes, but mine
Is knowne to sense; we gather odours there; wealthy
In their native sweetenesse, flowers of a hew
As bright as lasting, roses and lillies
Blowne from their stalkes, meete here, and dwell upon
Her cheekes, as if there onely they were priviledg'd
To enjoy an everlasting spring.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Let your
Imaginations seed even to a surfet, your senses
Are too too weake, and narrow t'entertaine
The bounteous flowing of her pleasures:
You'le let so much passe by unknowne,
As if you tooke but tribute of her blessings:
When the whole stocke is yours.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: We'le be her Mars, and meete her in soft skirmish,
In amorous duell, where we'le softly yeeld
And let her winne: (to raise her to the pride
Of a new victory, as much upon our selves
As we have done upon her Country,
Then shall shee binde us gently in her haire
Fetters for Captive lovers, and in scorne
Of our trimme youth, and temperate blood, when we
Begin to faint within her armes, shall then
Supply us with new strength from her own eyes;
Whence she will dart a soule at every glance
Rich as her selfe, and the blest smiles t'is made of;
Create an active flame within our breast
Able to give old statua's life and motion,
Make their stiffe marble feete supple as the joynts
Of love:— oh I'me lost! my Venus
Come; lead to my Venus.

sp.speaker: Urs:
sp.l: Your Cynthia,— your Moone
sp.stage: Curteine drawne, Felicia discovered lying upon a bed, Zisco, as having ravish't, and then slain her.
sp.l: With a man in her— there there's
Your way, why move you not?
How you stand.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: Ursini, Ha! Se'st thou that blacke thing there?
That ugly fiend, I'le out stare thee, devill.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Where are you Sir?

sp.speaker: Zis:
sp.p: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: Ravish't! Calantha's ravish't— oh torment!
Grim fury post to hell.

sp.speaker: Zis:
sp.l: Pardon mee Sir,
I've a little businesse to dispatch first—
This for Felicia, thus Alberto fell.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Oh I'me wounded.

sp.speaker: Zis:
sp.p: Ha! do'e know mee Prince?

sp.speaker: Urs:
sp.p: Frederico! just heavens.

sp.speaker: Zis.
sp.l: Stay your hand— be innocent in your revenge,
Let me beare all the guilt.

sp.speaker: Urs:
sp.l: Could'st thou thinke, dull Prince, that heaven so
Doated on thy royaltie, thy crowne, thy scepter,
Or regall pall could beare thee out in sin?
Or the weake shine of triviall state dazle
Their eyes that looke upon the blessed sunne!
Could'st thou flatter thy selfe into such a Security,
That vengeance would not finde thee out?
When thou had'st forfeited thy luxurious palate
With all the dainties of Felicia's body
Thirsted her blood, quaff'd off whole bowles of it,
Till thou wer't drunke, and wild with fury
Of thy intemperate draughts— Am not I a rare villaine now?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Mad, starke mad, besides himselfe,
Sure this is but a dreame, and I asleepe.

sp.speaker: Zis:
sp.p: Thus, thus I'le wake you:—

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: Oh my blood scalds, h'has shot wild fire into my heart,
Ah traytour, thy steele is poyson'd.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Frederico, let mee embrace thee:
Now our revenge is perfect.
sp.stage: A noyse within. Enter fighting, Valenzo, Grutti, Gonçales, Cassio, Calantha.

sp.speaker: Grut:
sp.p: Your passage lyes this way.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: Thorough us.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.p: Treason, treason, raise the Court.

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.p: Breake ope the doores.

sp.speaker: Urs:
sp.p: We are betray'd.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.p: Villaine I greete thy heart.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: Where tends your businesse?

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.p: Slave to hell, and thou shalt carry't thither.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Fire, fire, the poyson boyles my entrals.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.p: The Prince wounded!

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.p: Where are the traitours?

sp.speaker: Zis:
sp.p: Here I am his murtherer.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.p: Frederico.

sp.speaker: Urs:
sp.p: Valenzo, I am o'recome.—

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p:
New miracles, Calantha, my best my dearest love:— Oh I am sicke, stand off Calantha, my breath's so hot, 'twill singe thee else; and licke thy beauty's up, like nimble flames;
But dost thou live?

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: To curse thee false and perjur'd.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: The spheares are out of tune; nature's distraught;
The orbes celestiall have turn'd round so long
That they are giddie: the starres are in a mutiny,
The Intelligences are altogether by'th eares.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Heaven! I blesse your justice:
Sterne tyrant! that triumph'st o're the memory
Of my father, mock'st mee with love,
Till like a foole I doated on my fetters,
'Cause they were golden ones, that thus
Thy devillish art might make my soule a captive,
With my body.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Aenigmaticall.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Yet then a Lady mourn'd thy perjur'd vowes.
Whom thou betrayd'st to loose adultery.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Thy speech, Calantha, is darker than an Oracle.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Truer it is, and dar'st thou yet dissemble it?
'Tis a truth precious to time, who will preserv't
To blast thy memory, and derive a staine
On all thy successours.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: How? or when arriv'd this your knowledge Madame?

sp.speaker: Zis.
sp.p: How? or when arriv'd this your knowledge Madame?

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Felicia told mee all her selfe
Confirm'd it by religious oathes; besides
This medall which she gave mee from her necke,
A pledge of his broke faith, with the sad fruits
Of his sate lust, within her wombe.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: She's a blacke whore: shee lies; beleeve her not.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Thou wilt be damn'd:

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: So may I; and houle eternally
In those blew flames the devils bath in,
If ever my vowes were made to any other
Then thee; and those, as spotlesse as thy soule.—

sp.speaker: Urs:
sp.p: But whom have wee here?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Felicia! Sad Lady she intreated
This night's exchange of place; that she might shew him
What an untimely mother he had made her,
And this 'twas caus'd my flight,

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Felicia!

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Ha! murder'd.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: My love.

sp.speaker: Zis.
sp.l: My sister! ravish't:
And murder'd by! mee, incestuous villaine!

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Didst thou not tell mee that Ferrando ravish't her,
And cast her to his slaves, a prey to their
Bold appetites and furies.

sp.speaker: Zis.
sp.l: To incense you the more against him; I told you
What I onely did imagine, because at my returne
From Sicily, report whisper'd her lost,
Lost in the ruines of my Father,
Which made mee thinke her murder'd.

sp.speaker: Urs:
sp.l: Ye Gods! I now acknowledge you supreame:
Your power is mighty over our fond arts.
Silly projectours we ensnare our selves!
Whilst we spread nets for others.
This braine has wrought all these sad plots,
Calantha, take your Lord; who is as true,
And holy in his vowes, as those blest Saints
He invok't.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: And yet Felicia wrong'd?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: 'Twas I by whom she swell'd, and not Ferrando,
As 'twas suppos'd.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Suppos'd! she swore 'twas hee.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Ursini, farewell; I'le heare the rest anon—

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: That aggravates my crime, who wrought her into
This false beliefe, for having long lov'd her,
Without returne of mutuall flames, and at length
Finding that the impediment was her fond
Dotage upon the Prince; I determin'd,
Rather than not to be possest of her,
To part with faith and loyaltie, feign'd all
My visits for him, courted her acceptation
Of his love, which I so darkly brought about
That she consenting to private meetings
As oft as she expected the Prince,
I my selfe fill'd her armes.—

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Then you conclude Ferrando innocent?

sp.speaker: Urs:
sp.p: In act, or thought.

sp.speaker: Zis:
sp.l: Felicia! sister! your brother Frederico call's,
She's gon, cold, cold! and pale, and yet methinkes
She smiles, looke up, Felicia—

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: But how came it to passe she nere discry'd you?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: For reasons I then gave her: all our meetings
Were in the night, and that i'th darke too, where I
Dissembled so the Prince in voyce and gesture.—

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: This agrees right with her relation: villaine thou haste undone mee.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: And my selfe too.

sp.speaker: Zisc.
sp.p: Death hangs upon her lids, 'tis eternall night with her. hoa, sister, stay, take mee along with you; I'le follow you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pernicious traytour.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Rage choakes my utterance:— give mee your sword.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Our hearts and hands are yours:

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Our hearts and hands are yours:

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Ile be an age in killing thee, do'st tremble?
Thou look'st like one of those thin frozen ghosts,
That chattering lye on hils of thicke-ribb'd Ice,
Come meete my fury.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Here, here's my heart.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: I: I'le dig it out,
And cast it to the hungry fiends.

sp.speaker: Zis:
sp.p: My strength decayes, I reele and totter like a crack't reed that leanes against the windes.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Take your sword.—

sp.speaker: Urs:
sp.p: Madame.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Take it I say.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You do him too much honour.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Manag't with skill and strength, or thou affront'st
My honour,— faint-hearted! coward, I'le follow thee to hell.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Mercy heavens!

sp.speaker: Zis.
sp.p: Ho! Charon, more company, lye farther there jolt-head, what quarrelling you dogs? thy oare, thy oare ferriman: clap 'em o'th sconce with't, there, there.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: The Gods are just.

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.p: You wore their cause upon your sword.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: 'Tis poore revenge this, can he not live againe?
Start up from th'earth with life, and double strength?
Wer't centupled I'de meete him:— but oh my eyes!
Looke here Valenzo: which is Prince, which subject,
Which is my lov'd Ferrando? I see there is
No ceremonious state, no pompe in death;
They all lye levell, all quiet, the bad as well
As the good, why should this traytour here
This divellish arch, arch-traytour lye as silent
As his Lord? should he not stare, and foame,
Start up and howle, till he wakes all the dead?

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.p: Lady:

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.p: Her old passion returnes againe.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: — Roare, and curse heavens,
But they too have forgot to punish sinners,
And reward vertue, here's an example on't;
We were both vertuous, and deserv'd not this
Bad usage; let mee embrace thee:—
Cold as the earth he lyes on, and as dull too:
Where is the soule, that busie flame that lent
Him life and motion? affected such vaine pompe
And glorious noyse: whither is't fled? poore livelesse trunke,
It was unkindly done to leave thee thus,
A prey to wormes and rottennesse.

sp.speaker: Zis.
sp.l: Are you there fury, Megaera, Tisiphone, Alecto,
Howle, howle, furies, I'le lash you.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Kind death th'art welcome; I kisse thy dart.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: The Princesse! she's slaine, unluckie hand.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Spight of our starres, and all rude opposition,
We are one in death: Valenzo see us interr'd,
Both in one tombe, that we may mingle ashes
And be securely lodg'd, you know our soules
Were one; our hearts were long united.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: A FATALL UNION.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Draw, draw the curteines there, my love and I
Must sleepe;— uncivill I protest, put out the lights,
We shall sleepe best i'th darke; pray don't disturbe us,
You may fright him from mine armes,— but— I'le— hold— him— fast.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The ruin'd treasure of two Kingdomes
In one heape.
sp.stage: Enter Charintha, Piero, Violetta, Florinda, Alphonso.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: In the bed-chamber! this way!

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.p: Yes Lady, the cry was full of horrour.

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: 'Twas the Physitians potion this my Lord.

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.p: Done in revenge.

sp.speaker: Alph:
sp.p: Would 'thad bin poyson.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: Blesse mee! whence all these tragedies.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.p: Astonishment ceizes mee.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: The King:

sp.speaker: Calantha:
sp.p: Ursini dead. ha! whom have we here, Frederico,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes, and Felicia too.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: All slaine; by what dire hand?

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.l: I'le tell you that within.—
Charintha is your Queene.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.p: May you be happy in her love.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.p: Remove the bodies, i'th morning we will take order for the state, and funerall rites.

lg.l: Of these; the lasting story of whose wrongs
Shall be all royall lovers evening songs.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: AFter these ruines, thus your Poët stands,
Expecting his owne destiny from your hands,
By them he lives or dies; if it should hap
That stead of a mild doome, applause or clap.
Meete with harsh whispers, or halfe stifled jeeres,
Such unkinde censure kils him; his sad Muse
Unlesse you give her bay, has vow'd to use
The Cypresse wreathes, her pietie did allow
Those onely to incircle her owne brow:
New life and soule to his lost Poesie;
His flame's but sicklie yet, your breath no doubt
Will either blow't up higher, or quite out.
